messageBody:
Hmmm...some excellent points being made here. Some things I hadn't thought
about before. I kind of agree with you Ilja that if you've got something
that complex, then it might indicate that it may need to be pulled out on
its own. However I can also see that there could be plenty of situations
where that would not be appropriate.

In my experience most private methods are typically helper methods and not
of the high complexity variety that Nic described. I think it would be
overkill to test these. I have always worked to the rule of thumb that you
test the externally visible interfaces, and I think that is still valid for
the majority of cases. I accept though that there may be situations where it
may be beneficial to take things to a deeper level of granularity. If that
is the case how do people do this? The only way I can think of is to use
reflection.

Matt



-----Original Message-----
From: Ilja Preu?
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Sent: 23/05/01 15:00
Subject: AW: [junit] How to test protected and private methods/ fields?

> As a specific example, say I've got some computation that
> involves a fairly
> hairy algorithm in one place. I probably want to encapsulate
> that algorithm
> into its own method so, e.g., I can Substitute in a new
> Algorithm later when
> someone points out that I (again) made the problem a lot
> harder than it needed
> to be. I may well want to make that method private, though,
> as its existence
> or signature could reveal more about the internals of my
> class than I'd like;
> it might, e.g., have an argument that refers to a component
> of some (private) field.

You could put the algorithm in its own class. So you could test it
through
the public interface of the algorithm class without breaking
encapsulation
of the client class. Additionally you could easily use an other
algorithm by
just pluging in an alternative implementation (without having to rewrite
the
client class).

ciao, Ilja
